content:
Streptococcal arthritis: Causes, signs, treatment and prevention

Streptococcal arthritis is a very rare bone and joint disease. However, the disease has a major negative impact on the health and life of patients. Therefore, as soon as you notice symptoms of the disease, you should quickly go for examination and treatment to prevent dangerous complications.

What is streptococcal arthritis?
Streptococcus bacteria are bacteria that exist on the skin and mucous membranes of the human body. When the body is in a healthy state, this bacteria will not cause harm. However, if resistance is reduced, streptococcus will find every way to penetrate inside the body. At that time, they combine with other types of bacteria such as staphylococcus aureus, blue pus bacillus... to attack the joints, damage and inflame the joints, causing streptococcal arthritis. (first)
See more: What is arthritis?
The culprit causing the disease is Streptococcus bacteria

Is streptococcal arthritis dangerous?
Streptococcal arthritis can progress very quickly. When not detected and treated promptly, patients can face serious complications such as: (2)
Joint damage: bacteria attack all joint structures, corroding cartilage and bones and can cause loss of function, hindering the patient's life and health.; Damage to organs: through the bloodstream, bacteria can move into internal organs, causing infections, systemic infections, which can endanger the patient's life.

The cause to the illness
Streptococcal arthritis often appears after damage to the skin or some nearby organs or sepsis. The main causes of the disease are: (3)
Mechanical agents: skin damage, joint injury, open joint capsule tears will create conditions for bacteria from the outside to penetrate the joint.; Infections appear next to the joints such as boils, tendonitis, muscle inflammation, bone inflammation, urinary tract infections, digestive tract infections or genital infections near the joints... These are factors that directly affect development. streptococcal arthritis; The patient has had arthrocentesis or joint injection procedures performed without proper technique or sterility.; Due to infections in other organs such as pneumonia or sepsis, bacteria travel through the bloodstream to the joints.
In addition, the disease is also common in subjects such as:
People with poor resistance and are susceptible to infections such as children, pregnant women, and the elderly.; People with diabetes; People with malnutrition; People with bone and joint diseases such as joint injuries, gout, rheumatoid arthritis, etc.

4. Signs and symptoms of the disease
Patients with streptococcal arthritis will have symptoms such as: (4)
Symptoms in joints: Patients often have pain in infected joints, especially hip joints, knee joints, shoulder joints, wrist joints, elbow joints... Accompanying symptoms are inflammation, swelling, heat, and some redness. In cases where pus may leak. Inflamed joints often have severe, continuous pain, which increases with movement; Whole body symptoms: Patients often have high fever of about 39°C - 40°C, chills, weight loss, fatigue, dirty tongue, dry skin...; Extra-articular symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes at the corresponding inflammation site, some signs of initial infection may appear.

How to prevent streptococcal arthritis?
You should proactively take disease prevention measures such as: (5)
It is necessary to thoroughly treat infections when they appear, especially skin and soft tissue infections. Regularly exercise to improve the immune system and increase bone and joint flexibility; You should visit reputable medical facilities to receive appropriate antibiotics, perform drainage, arthroscopic lavage, and correct surgical techniques to limit the risk of serious infection causing joint destruction.; When you have a joint injury, you should actively treat and clean the wound according to your doctor's instructions. This will help prevent the risk of joint infections.; Develop a scientific diet to avoid uncontrolled weight gain and obesity. When you control your weight well, the pressure on your joints will be significantly reduced.

Diagnosis of streptococcal arthritis
Clinical diagnosis
People with streptococcal arthritis need to provide complete information about their current condition as well as the progression of the disease from the beginning and medical history. These are important data that help doctors make an accurate diagnosis.
Test
Blood tests: Doctors check the number of polymorphonuclear white blood cells, C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, pro-calcitonin.; Joint fluid test: The doctor punctures the joint to do cell count, gram stain, and pus culture to look for bacteria. Color and odor characteristics of joint fluid can also suggest a bacterial joint infection.
Blood culture
The doctor will take a blood sample from the patient and culture the bacteria. Thereby, doctors can identify the strain of disease-causing bacteria traveling in the blood to come up with an appropriate treatment plan.
Diagnosis by imaging
The doctor may prescribe X-rays, ultrasound or MRI to determine the location and extent of damage to the joint.
The process of diagnosing the disease is relatively more complicated than diagnosing common bone and joint diseases. However, once the correct bacterial strain and level of joint damage have been determined, treatment will no longer be too difficult.

Methods of treating arthritis caused by streptococcus
Treatment regimen
Medical treatment: The disease is initially treated with empirical intravenous antibiotics. Then, depending on the results of bacterial culture, antibiogram (checking the level of drug resistance of bacteria), and disease progression, the duration of antibiotic use, as well as the type of amenorrhea, can be changed.; Arthroscopy, aspiration and drainage: In addition to antibiotic treatment, the doctor may prescribe drainage of joint pus, joint lavage, etc.; Surgical treatment: In cases of severe infection, damaged joints and bones, the doctor may consider prescribing bone removal surgery, placing biological cement, etc.
Some measures to combine treatment with antibiotics: Pain relief, fever reduction with paracetamol, anti-inflammatory combination when there are symptoms of severe pain and high fever. Provides adequate nutrition for the body as well as controls existing chronic diseases.

This is also one of the pioneer units in diagnosing and treating musculoskeletal diseases with modern techniques according to updated international protocols.
The hospital is also equipped with modern machinery and imaging equipment such as: Somatom Drive 768-slice CT scanner, new generation Magnetom Amira BioMatrix magnetic resonance machine, Artis Pheno robot, densitometer. bones, ultrasound machines...; Opmi Vario 700 Zeiss surgical microscope system, Meera-Maquet operating table... to be able to detect injuries early and effectively treat musculoskeletal diseases...
Tam Anh General Hospital also owns a spacious clinic system and high-class boarding area; modern rehabilitation area; Comprehensive post-operative care process helps patients quickly recover and stabilize their health after surgery.

In addition to using medication or treatment methods as prescribed by your doctor, you should also change your diet and healthy lifestyle to bring about the best treatment results.
